section.title: Identity concepts
section.para: Before you begin using the &CIS;, make sure you understand the following key concepts:

listitem.para: A user is a digital representation of a person, system, or service that uses &CLOUD; services. Users have credentials and can be assigned tokens. Based on these credentials and tokens,the authentication service validates that incoming requests are being made by the user who claims to be making the request, and that the user has the right to access the requested resources.

In the &CLOUD; Users are represented as accounts created for specific individuals. When a user is created, the &CIS; automatically assigns a user type and a default role based on the &CIS; system configuration. Users with suffficient access rights and privileges can change user role assighments if required.

See the following links for more information:
"Identity users types and default roles"
“Assigning Roles to Account Users”
“Identity user types and default roles”
“Assigning Roles to Account Users”

Any kind of information that can be used in verifying an identity. For the &CIS;, credentials might include these types of information:
a matching username and password
a matching username and API key
a unique token issued to you
secret question and answer
verified cell phone number or email address
The act of passing in credentials, confirming an identity, and returning a token representation of the verified identity. In the &CLOUD;, credentials are typically a username and API key.

In the &CLOUD;, you authenticate by submitting a POST tokens API request with valid credentials to the &CIS; endpoint. Credentials are typically a username and API key. However, additional types of credentials can be accepted based on service, tenant, or user account configuration.

In response to valid credentials, the service returns an authentication token and a service catalog with information about the &CLOUD; resources that you have permission to access. You can use the authentication token and the service endpoint to submit service requests through the &CIS; API or any other service API that is included in the catalog.

The act of verifying the capability of an authenticated user, system, or process to perform an action on a set of resources. In the &CLOUD;, the Identity service provides centralized authorization to ensure that clients have appropriate access to information and information processing capabilities based on &CIS; roles such as system administrator and user administrator. The &CLOUD;, also supports Role-based access control which defines product-specific roles to authorize capabilities at the service-level.
A token is a temporary, encrypted form of identification that is passed to services as a proof of identity.

In the &CLOUD; an authenttication token is an encrypted string returned by &PRODNAME; in response to an authentication request submitted with valid credentials. The response also includes a service catalog with a list of &CLOUD; services that can be accessed with the token.
To access a service, include the authentication token in each request submitted to through the service API.
Authentication tokens expire after 24 hours. To get a new token, users must submit another authentication request to the &CIS;.
Authentication tokens expire after 24 hours. An administrator or process can revoke a token before its expiration, if necessary. To get a new token, you must submit another request to the &CIS;.
A tenant is a container that can be used to group or isolate resources and identity objects. Depending on the service provider a tenant can map to a customer, account, organization, or project.

In the &CLOUD;, tenants allow service providers to organize computing and storage resources without assigning them to user accounts directly. For example, Virtual machines (Cloud Servers) and containers (Cloud Files) are assigned to tenants, not to users directly.

&CLOUD; has two tenant types:
The Mosso tenant (Mosso account) ncludes the collection of resources commonly associated withservices such as Cloud Servers, Cloud Database, Cloud Load Balancers.
The NAST tenant (NAST account) includes the collection of resources commonly associated with Cloud Files and Cloud Files CDN.

Typically, a service provider determines how tenants are defined and used. The &CIS; allows service administrators to create, delete, enable, and disable tenants. Service administrators can also assign users and groups to one or more tenants. Because each tenant can have its own role configuration, user might have different roles, or different rights and privileges for the same role on different tenants.

A service is a logical name for the internal and external capailities provided by a &CLOUD; platform or product component. A service provides one or more endpoints through which users can access resources and perform operations.
In &CLOUD;, any system or product that can access the &CIS; API service such as Cloud Servers, Cloud Load Balancers, and Cloud Files is considered a service.

&CIS; allows you to define services, which are logical names for parts of &CLOUD; that provide internal or external capabilities, for things such as identity services, as well as compute and storage services.
A service provides one or more endpoints through which users can access resources and perform operations. Examples of &CLOUD; services include Identity, Servers, Load Balancers, and Files.
A network accessible addresss, usually described by a URL, where a service can be accessed.
Various &CLOUD; systems query the &CIS; for the service endpoints required to complete processes and operations. Users must know the URL for a service endpoint in order to use the service.

To get the URLs for other service endpoints, submit an authentication request with valid credentials to a &CIS; endpoint. After successful authentication, the &CIS; returns an authentication token and a service catalog with information about available services, including the endpoints to access each service.
In &CIS; version 1.1, an endpoint was known as a baseURL.
A network accessible addresss, usually described by a URL, where a service can be accessed.
Various &CLOUD; systems query the &CIS; for the service endpoints required to complete processes and operations. Users must know the URL for a service endpoint in order to use the service.

To get the URLs for other service endpoints, submit an authentication request with valid credentials to a &CIS; endpoint. After successful authentication, the &CIS; returns an authentication token and a service catalog with information about available services, including the endpoints to access each service.
In &CIS; version 1.1, an endpoint was known as a baseURL.
Service developers can create and delete endpoints. They can also define region-specific service endpoints for the same service API to customize service availability and operation by region.
Endpoint templates provide Cloud Service providers with a method to manage API service endpoints that apply to many or all tenants without having to add each endpoint on each tenant manually.

For example, a Service developer can define a global endpoint template that endpoint is automatically included in the Service catalog for all tenants authorized to use that service. The endpoint template also specifies the URLs for the internal, administrative, and public endpoints that provide access to the service.
See “Endpoint Templates” for detailed information.

A role is a common security construct for assigning a specific set of access rights and privileges to a user or group of users. Service administrators can create named roles, configure the rights and privilieges for each role, and manage the role without updating individual user or group accounts assigned to the role.

Roles can be assigned to users, groups, or tenants automatically based on organization security policy. An administrator can view, manage, and update role configuration and assignments as required. Only &CIS; service administrators can create new roles.

&CIS; supports two types of roles:
Global roles
A global role defines access and permissions across all Rackspace systems, administrator or user-administrator, for example. Global roles are different than product roles as they indicate whether the user is acting as a service or as a customer.
Product roles
A product role defines the functions a user can perform for a particular Rackspace cloud service.

A user with a specific role inherits the rights and privileges associated with the role. In &PRODNAME;, the authentication token issued to a user includes the list of roles associated with the user. When a user calls a service" >service, the service configuration determines how the user roles are interpreted. A role that grants access to certain resources or capabilities within one service can grant access to completely different resources and capabilities when interpreted by a different service.

RBAC is method to restrict service access to only authorized users. RBAC allows customers to specify who has access to resources and capabilities within their cloud deployment, based on roles defined by Rackspace. For example, an administrator can use RBAC to manage access to Cloud Servers as well as the permissions to complete operations such as adding and deleting servers after access has been granted.
